oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Anita Bryant Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Tape 1 of 2. Recording of an interview with Anita Bryant (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Anita Bryant; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie directs Anita Bryant away from mic -- (00:10) Bryant greets herself -- (00:13) Bryant tells about talking with Collie during a radio spot radio spot -- (00:21) Bryant attempts audiobiography radio spot with Collie correcting her and Bryant does a retake -- (00:43) Bryant attempts audiobiography radio spot with Collie telling her to be more playful and Bryant does a retake -- (01:16) Bryant thirty minute radio spot -- (01:26) Bryant midway point radio spot -- (01:40) Bryant audiobiography radio spot for a commercial break -- (01:53) Thirty minute remaining radio spot -- (02:04) Bryant misspeaks Collie's name and does a outro radio spot retake -- (02:22) Collie asks Bryant to do a couple more radio spots -- (02:34) Bryant radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (02:40) Collie instructs Bryant on a Music City Album Review and to mention her album -- (03:04) Bryant radio spot of the Music City Album Review and her album Anita With Love Volumes One and Two -- (03:18) Collie instructs Bryant on album review radio spot -- (03:35) Bryant messes up radio spot of the Music City Album Review and her album Anita With Love Volumes One and Two (03:51) Bryant radio spot of her album Anita With Love Volumes One and Two and the Music City Album Review -- (04:01) Collie instructs for simplicity the directions for the show and Bryant jokes about payment -- (04:40) Collie continues to ask Bryant about album details -- (05:04) Bryant tells Collie that the track he had listed was incorrectly listed as Marie Osmond instead of hers then discusses using other people's tracks -- (06:08) Bryant tells Collie "Paper Roses," "Til There Was You," and "My Little Corner of The World" were not written by her but performed live -- (07:20) Collie talks about small print and a Peggy walks in on set -- (07:50) Bryant introduces her first song, mentions her pageantry experience, and dating Kenny Rodgers -- (09:21) Collie and Bryant discuss Paper Roses and how it is known as a Marie Osmond song -- (09:58) Bryant discusses "Out Here On My Own" as a performing number -- (10:30) "I Won't Last A Day Without You" is described as a love song -- (10:50) Marie Osmond and Bryant's connection to "My Little Corner of the World" is discussed and Collie mentions that Sunny James had originally produced "Paper Roses" -- (11:48) Collie mentions Bette Midler on the Grammys and Bryant calls her gutsy -- (12:17) Collie and Bryant discuss Bryant's value system, how it influenced her performances, and roly-poly toys -- (13:54) Collie and Bryant talk about how she fringes between contemporary and country with her background of church and Opry -- (15:00) Bryant talks about her families country heritage and Little Jimmy Dickens -- (15:30) Bryant and Collie talk about what being on the Opry would mean to her -- (15:56) "Til There Was You" is talked about in conjunction with her first pageant -- (17:42) "Two Late Roses" by Bryant is described as a nob to a person from Selma and "Paper Roses" -- (19:04) Bryant and Collie talks about Lionel Richie giving feedback on "Two Late Roses" -- (19:44) Bryant talks about almost joining the Boone family -- (20:52) Bryant talks about heartbreak and life experience leading to multi dimensional writing -- (22:19) Collie talks about Johnny Russell describing writing as a necessity for healing and Bryant agrees -- (23:16) "Don't Cry Out Loud" is joked about and Bryant calls it a gutsy song -- (24:00) "What The World Needs Now" is talked about by Bryant as a necessity for the world to recognize love -- (25:47) Bryant talks about the double standards of action versus talk and Collie responds with a memory of his mothers death -- (27:27) Bryant talks about working with a publisher and discovering a book named The Art of Mentoring -- (30:00) Collie talks about how modern times are more hands off teaching and Bryant responds with declaring how much people are observed -- (31:51) Collie shifts gears and talks about "Had To Be You" and Shelby Lynne cutting the track -- (32:18) Bryant talks about having a manger who would teach her older ballads to expand her knowledge -- (33:05) Collie and Bryant talk about Willie Nelson and recording of older tracks -- (33:50) Bryant talks about performing "What Will I Do" and Collie talks about what Eddy Arnold believed to be the most important part of his show -- (34:50) Bryant talks about drawing an intimacy with a crowd and "The More I See You" -- (35:31) "My Romance" is discussed by Bryant as only needing the man you love -- (35:55) Collie and Bryant talk about "You'll Never Know" and Collie's personal connection -- (36:18) I'll Get By" is said to be a simplistic swing -- (37:39) Anita With Love production is addresses as a live to two track -- (40:15) Bryant gives the 1-800 number and direct mail address for the album -- (41:00) Bryant and Collie talk about bringing Bryant back on the show to discuss her other volumes of Anita With Love -- (41:48) Bryant gives her sign off
